number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												All my life I've been searching; searching for something with meaning, something I could tell my grandkids I accomplished with a big grin on my face. Education was always tough for me, I was never any good at sports, I was mediocre at best when it came to music, and making friends just wasn't there for me.  On May 16th I planned to take my life... It was raining outside, I took my Mom's SUV to the local state park near my house. The gate was locked so I just hopped over it with nothing but a rope. I found a nice big oak tree that would guarantee my demise, I tied the noose and put it around my neck while saying to myself "This is life has no meaning". IN the moment between life or death I was saved, my phone vibrated and I looked at the notification, "You have received a gift copy of Goat Simulator". This was a sign, the sign I was looking for. I ran back to the SUV and raced home with tears in my eyes because finally things were looking up.  I ran upstairs and booted up my PC while nervously tapping my fingers. I downloaded the game while drinking myself drunk with Mountain Dew (diet I might add), and launched the game. I immediately broke down on my knees sobbing at the loading page because in that moment it told me "You are worth something, you mean something to me".  After playing the game for a few hours I got a call from an old girlfriend asking if we could make things work, after a few more my Dad came to my room and told me he was going to stop drinking, and finally when I finished the game I walked outside and literally drowned in ♥♥♥♥♥ and hot pockets. Words can't express what this game has done to me, and I hope one day I will be able to repay this game for saving my life, but for now all I can say is; Thanks Goat Simulator.... You're a savior.

Posted: April 9, 2014
												This is one of those games I felt lived up to my expectations and surpassed them. It is definately a great value for the price as I have had a blast playing this game with my four year old who finds the game as hilarious and silly as I do. He quickly learned how to play the game and has been enjoying the open world aspect of it (his favorite type of games). With Steam Workshop already in place and free content already annoumced, I look forward to see what is in store for this game with great delight. When I attempted to set up the controls for this game on a Steam Controller, I did not have much success. I hope to see that changed as I know it would increase how much fun I am having with the game. Better improvement for mods would be nice as it seems a number of them on Steam Workshop require a seperate installation of the game in 64bit. Thankfully the game does have a respawn function when game breaking glitches happen and you are left stranded in objects, in the ground, or in the air. With a game this zany, I would never expect realistic but a little bit better handling on the jumping in the game would be nice. Over all, this game is definately one of the best entertainment values I have stumbled upon in recent history. Sale or no sale, this game is worth every penny.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												You know, I've always wondered who buys all those "simulation" games. You know the ones, with the same Helvetica Ultra Compressed Italic title font, that offer bogglingly realistic looks at, say, farming, or truck driving, or other very specific career tracks. After doing a bit of research, it would seem to be a split between younger kids, for whom the rough-and-ready big machines appeal is strong, young adults looking into the subject at hand as a possible career idea, and middle-aged guys with a personal connection to the industry in question. Perhaps you want to be a construction worker, or a farmer, or a train engineer, or perhaps you were one once upon a time, before you took that arrow to the knee. Nonetheless, mocked as they tend to be by gamers, these games sell well, so obviously they have a market and they meet its needs.I suppose I'm wondering, then, if I'm a hyperannuated child who dreams of being a goat, a hyperannuated young adult considering a career in being a goat, or a middle-aged man who missed his calling to become a goat, and turns to this game to fulfill an unrequited dream of the yesterday I now can only wish I'd pursued while I was still young and vital, and all paths, including, one must presume, becoming a full-time goat, were available to me. (I'll leave the navel-gazing about my inner longhorn for another review.)Whichever of these *you* may be, however, I suspect you will be well satisfied by this game. Inasmuch as you have any latent, unrealized dreams of being a belligerent ungulate loose in a city's-edge suburb, this simulation will surely help you to actualize them. I'm really impressed by its quality; Coffee Stain claims this is a two-week coder-doodle, but I'm genuinely blown away by the realism, the attention to detail, and the care and craftsmanship of every nuance of my caprine second-life. The transition from trot to gallop shows not only an eye for physics, but an emotional journey for the protagonist, from gaining momentum to finding the rhythm of hooves and stabilizing the new run. It is one thing to create a game that merely *depicts* a goat running; it is another to immerse the player into the experience of being a running goat. I was, well and truly, a running goat, as I played. I felt the years melt away; I have no idea how many, nor whether they were human years or goat years, or what the exchange rate between them might be. I was too busy being a goat to care.This is a sandbox game. If you're looking for direction, you're welcome to follow the achievements trees and let them inspire you, but you need not even pay attention. In the course of your immersive goating, you will surely unlock more and more achievements, just by doing what comes naturally. Don't be afraid to bleat, or "baah" as the game calls it; your bleats are limited only by your desire to bleat, and this isn't some kind of goat-themed roleplaying game; you need not wait for your bleat meter to replenish to do it again. Timing headbutts during a charge can be tricky, yes, but again, this is not a goat-themed action game, it's a *simulation*. You'll get the hang of it soon enough, just keep trying. Don't worry, there are many, many things to butt, stomp, scatter and abuse.While you can certainly play the game in metadialogue with the protagonist, imagining yourself merely a spectral guide inspiring a goat who is not, in fact, yourself to move, bleat, butt, and grab things with a curiously elastic froglike tongue -- this is a mystery of goathood of which I had been previously unenlightened, and it was a surprise to me -- you will surely enjoy the game more if you let the simulation run wild in your imagination. For those of us without years of Stanislavsky Method training, this is well and truly our golden ticket into the mind, horns and hooves of the goat. Embrace the goat. Become one with the goat. To do less would be to fail to actualize the potential of this masterpiece of simulation.I ran as a goat. I headbutted as a goat. I climbed as a goat. I climbed *ladders* as a goat. And when that truck barreled out of the tunnel toward me, I didn't look up at it and see a giant rolling metal deathbringer. Oh no. I was a *goat*, baby, and all I saw was a rival in full charge. I bleated. I lowered my head. And I charged that sorry Peterbilt with the mightiest butt I could manage. Were there a nanny goat present, I would have surely emerged the dominant male from that challenge!I can't really speculate as to how well this game prepares one for becoming a goat professionally, as I have no plans to use this simulation as career training, as many do. Since it bears the textual laurels of the Helvetica Ultra Compressed Italic font on its cover and splash screen, however, I am fully confident that, like the mighty Microsoft Flight Simulator before it, it will prove useful to goats-in-training, although it may require specialized input hardware for a more realistic experience, as MSFS did. (I have no idea what specialized goat-simulation hardware looks like, maybe some of you awesome hardware experts can help me here.)I was not aware that I yearned to life a double life as a goat before playing this simulation game. After playing it, I remain no more convinced, really, that I ever wanted to be a goat. But if I did want to be a goat, this simulation would well and truly satisfy that desire in a deep, meaningful, lasting, and enlightening way. I can recommend this game not only to would-be goats, but even to those merely curious about what their lives might have been like, if they had chosen to be goats. I can even recommend the game to those who are merely curious as to what "being a goat" entails, and I suspect that the many souls who plunk down ten bucks just to see what all the fuss is about will want away both entertained and a little wiser.The line between simulation and reality becomes more and more fuzzy with every passing year. I shudder to think how many concussions this game could virtually induce if Oculus Rift support appears, down the line. The goat of tomorrow has finally arrived. Thank you so much, Coffee Stain!

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												This game is deeper than it would let us believe. The default map takes us to an area that straddles between an industrious and cosmopolitan city and the rural farm communities and suburbs. And as we quickly learn in this utter masterpiece, neither community is spared from the righteous fury of mother nature. Regardless of social-economic status, race, creed, the ever constant force of the universe will cut them all down in a sweeping and often chaotic gesture.Forests will grow and die,Oceans will form and dry away,Towering mountains will erode away into sand,The most humble of peasants, and even the mightiest of kings will grow old and die,And the twinkling stars that seem like our eternal audience will eventually burn out.You must purchase this game and experience the raw essence depicted within, and although you will not fully come to understand the universe around us by it alone, you will nevertheless acquire another small piece to the grand puzzle we call life.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												It's abundantly clear from the title (and the internet hype) that this game is silly, pure and unadulterated silliness. I make no apologies for saying that's enough to sell it to me. But is the game any good? What does it do? Is it worth buying (being perhaps the ultimate question)?Let's tackle what it is. Well, it says on the tin, as it were. It's a sandbox bugger-about (if that isn't a genre it damned well should be). Your goat emulates Tony Hawk in a rather straightforward (but oddly-sounding) way - you can jump, flip, headbutt, and lick - the latter which allow you to pick things up and wander around with them, flailing-weapon-like. As already stated, it's a free-for-all bugger around in a sandbox townscape. There are some collectables to find, game mode tweaks to unlock, and special tricks (usually with accompanying in-jokes) to perform; the latter being the real meat of the game.Is it any good, though? Yes and no.As before, it's patently obvious what it is, but the real downsides are that there is so little content here. The single environment is sadly very small, so you can easily find every nook and cranny therein within a couple of hours. But, somewhat worse, it does tend to tire some time before that; in other words, the chuckles wear thin fairly quickly, as they do with any joke once heard or experienced the first time. So, in such cases, you NEED something else to offer to fall back on, and sadly there just isn't enough for that.The tricks you need to perform (they are sequential, so you need to perform a given trick successfully before the next one appears) can also be romped through in short shrift, especially once you quickly work out the best places for performing them.So, the final question, is it worth buying? Well, the answer isn't really straightforward as it entirely depends on your own perspective.If you are OK with a couple of hours at best of silly entertainment, and the price is acceptable, then by all means go for it. It is what it is. The only warning I will add to this is to be prepared for some bad framerate issues - it isn't optimized at all at this point. My main desktop (a couple of years old) will potter along acceptably, if you consider drops to 30 FPS acceptable when you've busted up a few things (which means frequently). On my laptop which is above minimum recommended specs, forget it. 10 FPS is about it. That's the only real thing to beware.However, if you are a little more careful and considered with your purchases, then I would offer you a firm "no" for buying it - at least not yet.There's a couple of major reasons I say not yet. Firstly, the obvious one being as with all things Steam, a sale is imminent and there will be promotion soon enough. Secondly, from my experience with Coffee Stain studios, they are generally good guys. I bought Sanctum when it released, and the content was 3 (or maybe 4) maps at that time, but they added and updated repeatedly right up to the time before Sanctum2's release, so as far as money's-worth I DEFINITELY got it, as all this content was free. Their DLC was generous too, as they asked what we wanted to see as DLC and listened - so maps, in general, and they were well priced.I have no doubt they'll be adding to this game (and as of today have confirmed more free content for May), so it will improve. There is also the point that it has Steam Workshop support, and mods have been coming in pretty quick already, so I have no doubt this will be pretty well supported and will grow.So in summary, I'd urge to wait and get it in a couple of months.

												Goat Simulator is a joke of a game. You take control of a goat in a small town with absurd physics. A simple headbutt from the goat will blow up a car. The goat can climb ladders effortlessly and drag objects around with its tongue. The town is basically a small sandbox with several hours of things to do, but not much more than that.Goat Simulator is small, deliberately unpolished and buggy and its design is simple. But it is a really funny joke, full of great physics-powered slapstick humor and unexpected surprises in every corner of its seemingly peaceful small-town map.It is hard to recommend this game or even describe it, it is such a visual experience that you really should take a look at a video before buying and after that, either you want to move on, or you really need to play this game.Sounds 4/10Graphics 7/10Gameplay 8/10Atmosphere 10/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

number of helpful: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Goat Simulator is a misnomer. This is not a simulator of true goat life. This game is more like the Dark Souls of goat simulation and could be the deepest non-linear action rpg of our time.You start out in an open field with perhaps the most cliched of beginings, the amnesiac hero. Much in the vein of dark souls you know little about the world to begin with and will learn more through close observation of details. What's the deal with the standing stone circle? Who is behind the sinister experiments in the anti gravity science facilty? These are questions that you'll answer in your journey along with many more.Narrative is driven purely through your interactions with npcs. This is some of the best npc interaction I have seen as each npc has their own digital life and routine and they will remember your past interactions. Did you headbutt Kyle earlier? Well he's staying headbutted. The only gripe I have with the NPCs is that the AI is particularly poor and they only react directly to the player rather than to the world around them. However due to the non-linear nature of the game and story, this should be forgiven.Graphics are great and highly stylised. The world is vibrant and full of colour, making it easy to distinguish objects on screen. Likewise, the music is perfect and even contextual, ramping up at times of extreme action. Final word: Simple to learn, difficult to master with engaging gameplay and a deep and compelling non-linear narrative, Goat Simulator is a modern day classic and a must buy for all gamers, casual or hardcore.Score: 10/Goat

number of helpful: 13 of 19 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												Thoroughly enjoyed Goat Simulator 2014. Goat/10.Goat Simulator 2014 gives an in-depth experience that uses a wide range of engaging stimulus and challenges to educate us humans of the agricultural environment that a goat must endure through it's life. The inspiring story of Goat overcoming his/her oppressors (the humans) creates an amazing storyline, with numerous plot twists that will have you on the edge of your seat. I know what you're thinking, "but its just a goat!" Shut the hell up you fool, although this may be 'just a goat', this is 'just a goat' that broke through its goat expectations and stereotypes to face the world with nothing but its hyper-elastic tongue and it's oddly unnatural ability to not die. Ever. Goat Simulator 2014 expertly demonstrates how political views and actions can affect not only mankind, but also goats. It confronts the player with many terrifying situations (and can at times cause great offense). One example of this is the many rules and regulations imposed by the goverment, like what the hell? You want to keep me in this goat pen? Do you think this tower will keep me happy? This game allows you to fight the power, and essentially "♥♥♥♥ the police". The most controversial aspect of this game is most definitely the goat fight scene, where you must turn against your fellow goats for the pleasure of the humans. Who really wants to participate in a competitive blood bath of goats for someone else's entertainment? In my honest opinion, I would much rather prefer that to not be a part of the game. Although I may not be condoning goat on goat violence, I find mowing down the many so called 'innocent' civilians and sacrificing them to the Lord Satan gives me an enjoyable rush. This game has the potential to inspire many, whether they want to become a goat scientist, goat gymnast, goat astronaut, goat ball pitcher or whale, they will find this game absolutely enthralling. The Good Goat VS Bad Goat dynamic of Goat Simulator gives the player the ability to influence the goat's decisions, and essentially determine to be Good Goat, or Bad Goat. (I also have the sneaking suspicions that recent games such as Infamous: SECOND SUN (what does that even mean?) have copied this genius game mechanic from Goat Simulator 2014.)  I recommend this game as it accurately depicts the various aspects of survival that a goat must face in it's day to life, and does so in a way that us humans can relate to and take advice from in both an entertaining and interesting way. This game forces you to think. I love it.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Here you are once more, on the Goat Simulator page on Steam. No... no, don't leave yet. Stay awhile -- relax a bit, have some tea. Chamomile perhaps? It was always a favorite of mine, back in the old days in the Romanian countryside, where I grew to manhood alongside Scruffles, my pet bear. Scruffles was a gentle bear for the most part, but he was a deeply troubled soul. I could not forsee what terrible things he would do to that family. Sometimes I think back on it and wonder what more I could have done for him; wonder if there were any signs that I missed, or if I had ever been unkind to him in any way...Oh, but I forget myself again. I apologize. Let me stoke the fire one moment.... there... now where were we? Oh yes, the game. Yes, here you are once more, perhaps after a few days, or maybe even months. You've heard whispers about it, you've seen the videos, and perhaps you even watched a friend play it. You saw it listed once, you clicked on it -- you debated on whether or not you should dip into the money you were saving for your wifes anniversary dinner. Or perhaps you scoffed, your nose held high, unwilling to part with your hard earned cash in exchange for this utter rubbish. Whatever the case, you're back here, aren't you?Is it a Steam sale that now draws your attention? Perhaps it's always been on your list of games to buy? Or has the morbid curiosity in you reached that point of no return? Are you unable to restrain yourself from clicking that purchase button? Are you even okay?Don't answer that last question; you ARE okay. You will be okay. Everything from now on will always be.... okay. You see it wasn't just you that brought you back here for what could possibly be the fifth time... it was Goat. You don't know Goat, except that you do. Goat has always been with you, whether you're aware of it or not. The lingering presence, the angel on your shoulder, the devil in your gut -- all of it was Goat. Goat has been with you in your dreams. Goat was with you during your SAT's. Goat was there when you stood beside the pastor and watched your beloved walk down the isle.Goat was there. Goat was always there.And here you are again, reading this review, wondering whether or not you should purchase Goat Simulator; wondering if it will fullfill you in ways only few other games have. Or maybe you just wonder why you're back here again, after so many other visits, trying to figure out just what it is that compells you to return. Well there are no more questions you need to ask yourself now is there? There are no more questions because suddenly the way is clear.Goat is calling you home. From the moment you were born, Goat has been there with you, watching over you, waiting until you were worthy of the glory that lies beyond the purchase button. Every time you nearly touched it, it was Goat that slapped your hand away.... because you were not yet ready for the greatness. But Goat is calling you, and you can hear him now. Goat is waiting for you on the other side. The great beyond lies waiting for you -- it is a place of light, healing, transcendance... and whales. Lots, and lots of whales.But above all the great beyond is that one place you've always been walking towards though you never really knew it. It's Eden. It's Valhalla. It's the Stars. It's Goat Simulator.Come home to the great beyond. Come home to Goat.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												A true 2014 masterpiece.  It's hard to come to terms with the sheer magnitude of perfection this game offers to the world of want-to-be-goats.  But I will give it a shot.Story:  A gripping tale of love and betrayal, told from the perspective of a goat that must decide between his compassionate, love-driven upbringing and the dark, brooding forces that conspire to take him over.  10/10Graphics:  The goat has never been portrayed more accurately and in such an eye-pleasing way.  The game transcends what was once thought possible about depicting these fine creatures in gaming.  How many other games have you seen that feature goats so prominently?  That's because it is far too complex a task for any normal developer.  10/10Soundtrack:  The score of this game never fails to give the audience 100% immersion into the goat's perspective.  The music ranges from cheerful to borderline sinister.  It really draws the audience into how the goat feels at all times.  10/10Gameplay:  You are a goat.  You have at your disposal the tools necessary for destroying everything anyone has ever loved.  Could you possibly ask for anything else?  10/10Overall:  Do you like an engaging story?  Do you enjoy being truly immersed in a game by its versatile soundtrack and setting?  Do you want to be a god-forsaken goat?  This is the game for you.  Delete everything else off your machine, lock your doors, say goodbye to your loved ones:  from now on, this is your life.  11/10

												As soon as I had woken up, the bright light shined around me, as I came flying down the street on the back of a truck. Held by my tongue I began to build up speed and entered the bright Valhalla, also known as the petrol station. The man at the desk just gave me a death stare, as I flew through screaming and vigorously taking out the entire station leaving it in flames. This is truly a game for any goat fan.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												Goat Simulator began as a joke. This joke has now snowballed into what may be the greatest game of all time. Just when you think it can't get any weirder, this game will blow your mind. It has references to nearly every geeky thing you can think of, from The IT Crowd to South Park to Bravest Warriors.A lot of games out there have stupid achievements. As a completionist, I feel compelled to 100% each game in my collection even though it kills me a little inside. With Goat Simulator, you can breeze through all the achievements in a few hours if that's what you want - the mutations make it super easy. But I didn't take the easy route. For all its frustrating bits, I wanted to do everything this game has to offer, and I wanted to do it legit. Aside from a few gems like Super Meat Boy and VVVVVV, not many games can do that.If you want hours upon hours of replayable, sandboxy goodness with the option of getting serious now and then, Goat Simulator is for you.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												Every few years a game comes around, a game with wisdom, knowledge, redemption. With a story so thought provoking and intense you cannot help but cry a bit. A game that turns boys into men and girls into women. A game that sets the bar for future generations of games. Games like Super Mario Bros, Doom, Final Fantasy, and now Goat Simulator. ….. ok not really but it is a game about being a goat and you get to go destroy things, so it's still pretty awesome. Just finished my first run through (and trust me I ran through a lot of stuff XD) and I enjoyed it, for something so silly it is surprisingly fun. A lot of hidden things to find and hidden jokes if you take the time to look around. And you can always reset the world and try destroying things differently. Not to mention it has workshop support so who knows what the community will add.  If you want a fun crazy goat related experience that you can play over and over just go ahead and slap down 10 bucks and enjoy yourself, after all you may be a goat in your next life better be prepared!**(Reincarnation is not necessarily the belief of the reviewer, nor is he saying that this is in fact true or false. However for purposes of a joke he has put it in.)

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												I feel like Goat Simulator was overhyped. Sure it looks cute and fun with its silly goat protagonist and a general goofyness to the world. But there are only two area's in the game and if you don't have a fantastic computer this game runs like s***. To add on top of it the people in game are irritatating. Sure, it might be funny to hear "I was sacrifice by that goat!" ONCE. But when they repeat it over and over It just makes everyone else in the game to seem like lifeless puppets. Though not entirely related to the review the scream they use in the game must be some sort of royalty free scream because I've heard it in other games like SCP Containment Breach. And trust me, once you played that the scream does not fit in this game at all. Overall I just felt like I was getting achievements and had no other goal or fun thing to do other then that. It might entertain you for a few days but then it will soon be forgotten. Buy it on sale, but otherwise I couldn't reccomend.TL;DRPros-Goats-Physics-Sacrifice?Cons-Expensive Computer-Weird Voice Acting-Doesn't entertain for very long.6/10

number of helpful: 12 of 18 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												Quite possibly the best goat simulator I've ever played, no seriously!But seriously, remember back in the old days, when games were fun. We just played...for fun, spending hours playing certain games with no MP features just because they were great fun to play. These days, most games fail hardly at meeting that demand, half the time the games we play these days are MP, and we only do so to `get to the next level` or `unlock the next item` or we paly them simply because our friends are playing them.This game is unique, it succesfully fills that cliche of just being a thing to play on your own, for fun!However that said, there are some negatives. The map feels small, and the current stuff to do is fairly limiting. Providing the game gets updated with little bits of content from the workshop or the devs, I'm sure this game will continue to thrive, and remain my favourite 15 minute time killer.Also, the lack of being able to eat grass and poop is disturbing for a goat simulator. Please add that one!!Kog

												I'm a little late to this review, and, in a way, that's almost a good thing.You've probably heard about this game through: YouTube, Tumblr, Reddit, Your mate, Your mate's mate or your Mate's Mate's Mate's mate. Everyone praises this game, hail goat simulater! Lol 10 of- lol so random funny lol glitchy random funny lol ten random funny lol yolo! This game isn't funny, it really isn't if I can quote NerdCubed here "This game isn't YOLO it's LOLO, laugh out loud once, at one point you'll laugh once "Heh, man fell down" and thats it." And it's true, the main punchline, man fell down, game is teh glitch, and you may chuckle... Once, then after that this game just keeps pushing, and pushing, and PUSHING thats same joke down you ♥♥♥♥ing throat as you choke to death on a man falling down, and random glitches. The 1 defense is: "Oh, but it's supposed to be glitchy, it's parodying ♥♥♥♥♥♥ simulators" No! No no no! You see, if you try to make a bad game and succeed, then you've made a bad game (another Nerd3 quote) This game isn't parodying anthing, it's just adding to the pile of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ "Simulators" This is a game that was funny to some 12 year old, and then once Pewdiepie played it, the cult leader of the braindead 12 year old, "lol yolo 10 funny ranomd lol!" gang. Basically, you know that one kid at any school, that said some "Joke" that he thought was funny, wether it be towards someone or not, he said that "Joke" and one kid barley chuckled, and something clicks "Oh my god, someone- someone ♥♥♥♥ing laughed, I must be the funniest person ever!" And then every. Single. Day, he just said, and said, and said that joke over and over and over and over an over again. It wasn't funny the first time when that 1 out of 8 NPC models fell down, it wasn't funny when the goat flew out of the map, it was just annoying.Goat Simulator: "The bane of the ♥♥♥♥ing universe!"2/10And now I prepare for all the fans, rating this review down, and calling me a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, because that's what 12 year old's do.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												I'm not even sure whether to recommend this game or not. I understand that the main goal of this game are open world havoc for fun. There're a lot of silly effects and you can do funny things. But I didn't get the fun. I'm totally bored with the game, and it gets worst with the MMO Simulator update.I understand that they're trying to add something to do in-game rather than just pointlessly creating ruckus in the middle of the town. I guess that's just because there's nothing to do ? I'm not the achievement kind of guy. I don't really care about pursuing achievements since it gives you nothing. The graphics are okay, the gameplay is rather pointless, and I think the game's effort to give me fun is a huge fail. I saw a lot of positive reviews from other people and most of them don't play for long. This game is best fit to fill your free time when you're bored playing anything. But if you're also bored of crazy goats,walking toilets and two-legged microwave, this game will become totally useless.Note : Please,people.Do not give thumbs down to my review only because I didn't recommend your beloved game.Everyone has their right to express their opinion about the game in the review section.Remember the thumbs up or down is about whether my review is HELPFUL or NOT.It's not about whether I recommend a game you like or not.What's the point of rating my review if you love the game ? Why are you reading reviews if you love the game ? Why do you even read reviews when you ALREADY have the game ? I suppose a lot of people intentionally giving thumbs down because they hate people who aren't recommending a game they like.Maybe they're trying to cover up the bads of the game ? My review is for the people who don't know what kind of game is this and I want to help them to decide whether to buy this game or not.THAT is the purpose of a review.I truly hope you people are educated enough to comprehend this and STOP giving bad ratings to reviews that don't recommend a game you like.

												This game is honestly the biggest buyer's remorse I've ever had fo a game. It's funny... For five minutes. I'd bought it for about £7 and spent ten minutes on it before getting bored. content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Although you may know how to talk the talk and walk the walk... BUT can you goat the goat?Goat Simulator is a game of adventure, love, heartbreak, suspense, murder, and any other type of genre you can think of. You play as an indebted detective known as Bookshelf DeGoat sent on a mission by the iconic lettuce triplets to bring them the girl and wipe away the debt. You jump in a rocket and fly up to the floating haven (and by haven I mean sweat shop) of Alaska. Once there you will begin to notice the high amounts of patriotism and overpriced T-shirts manufactured by Starbucks. You learn about their leader, Celery Q. Cumquat, you enter a raffle then win only to find out you are known as the False Sheep. You fight hordes and hordes of Cumquat's men to reach the girl known as Goatlizabeth. As the duo run around the city of Alaska Goatlizabeth is shown to have supernatural powers to open ripples in space-time simply referred to as tears.I could go on about the plot but I won't spoil the rest of it for you. All I can say is that this is the greatest entry in Baashock franchise yet.Goat out of twelve-ty two would most certainly bangGoatOfTheYear

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												What does it mean, to be alive?  On a biological level this can be answered easily, but it becomes harder to answer as we approach it more philosphically.  Is life not constructed of the same matter as the rest of the universe?  Does a dead body not have the same amount of atoms as a living body?  Can you measure the soul?  Is sentience, nay, is consciousness something a living being can truly attain?  In the face of the infinite void of the universe, can a human claim to know anything at all?  Can a human truly understand anything, or is all of our culture and history nothing more than the filthy residue of our species' unending drive to eat, ♥♥♥♥, and kill?  Can any man claim to be superior to another man, to an ape, a goat, a snake, an ant?  Should we as a species be proud of our dominance over the Earth?  Have we, through our actions, proven to be noble and gracious caretakers of the only home we have?  I think not.  No, a man is nothing more than an unthinking beast with ersatz free will.  Mankind is a nuclear wolf wearing the skin of God, barking at itself in the mirror in a locked room full of its own excrement. Barking louder and louder, bared fangs slobbering radioactive saliva, until it's idiotic madness causes it's own heart to detonate.It is time to remove the mask of yourself.  Rip away the insincere facade of humanity from your ego.  Your leg is caught in the beartrap of society, and if you don't gnaw your leg off your spirit will starve to death.  Become the beast you already know you should be, deep down inside, and the taste in your mouth won't be your own blood, it will be the taste of freedom.  Play Goat Simulator.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												My first 5 minutes in the game should say enough...After a few short moments I was running around causing some good old Goat brand havoc. Headbutting cars, headbutting people into cars, licking random strangers and sharp objects. Even chasing strangers with random sharp objects.  While ceaselessly headbutting my way through the construction site I noticed a ladder on the backside of the sky crane. Without second thought, I scampered my body up it. Wobbly head and all.As the wind whipped around my stubby little legs and my head finally stopped twitching underneath my bloated belly due to smacking into the ladders rungs, I reached the first platform on the crane. Looking down back onto the construction site I couldn't help but see two NPCs standing... just standing.. It was as though the simple idle animations of fist pumping and partying were mocking me.So, I did what any good, reasonable and upstanding goat would do; I jumped on the woman first. Sending her into a nearby trampoline which ejected her into parts unknown.As my flailing body began to regain its balance and find its footing, I mashed the 1 key and tried to let out a long "BAAAAAAA" but instead belched out one of those Viral video goat screams which came off more like the attack cry of a minion from the 6th circle of Hell . The Fist pumping♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥nozzle was, of coarse by now, running full tilt and screeching bloody murder at the tops of his lungs.Unfortunately he didn't make it far as I began to mash E (lick) in his direction while flipping through the air screaming at him like some sort of nightmarish jet fuel.Somehow, I managed to grab hold of an explosive tank on the underside of my flip which sent the tank over my head with the momentum of my body and crashing to the ground with enough force to detonate the canister.... right next to a few more..Needless to say, the man was never seen again, I only caught a quick frame of him flying away at subsonic speeds engulfed in flames.I however was sent in the opposite direction and straight into the nearby gas station.I couldn't help but mash that magical "baaaa" key again followed quickly by the slow motion button.As my lifeless goat simulaid flew threw the air away from one explosion and was certain to cause another in a moment; I could only describe the scene as a Jon Woo ballet featuring a goat.. looking deeply into my slo-mo, crossed eyed screaming Billy...I knew I was in love.Pressing the slow motion key again, I flew head first at break neck speeds into a gas pump, sending the entire station up in a plume of smoke, debris and heat.MICHEAL BAY flashed on the screen as a combo multiplier.I hit escape.Sat for a moment.Let what I just did/witnessed sink in.Took a deep breath.Slid out of my chair.And laughed for five minutes on the floor.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												What does it mean, to be alive?  On a biological level this can be answered easily, but it becomes harder to answer as we approach it more philosphically.  Is life not constructed of the same matter as the rest of the universe?  Does a dead body not have the same amount of atoms as a living body?  Can you measure the soul?  Is sentience, nay, is consciousness something a living being can truly attain?  In the face of the infinite void of the universe, can a human claim to know anything at all?  Can a human truly understand anything, or is all of our culture and history nothing more than the filthy residue of our species' unending drive to eat, ♥♥♥♥, and kill?  Can any man claim to be superior to another man, to an ape, a goat, a snake, an ant?  Should we as a species be proud of our dominance over the Earth?  Have we, through our actions, proven to be noble and gracious caretakers of the only home we have?  I think not.  No, a man is nothing more than an unthinking beast with ersatz free will.  Mankind is a nuclear wolf wearing the skin of God, barking at itself in the mirror in a locked room full of its own excrement. Barking louder and louder, bared fangs slobbering radioactive saliva, until it's idiotic madness causes it's own heart to detonate.It is time to remove the mask of yourself.  Rip away the insincere facade of humanity from your ego.  Your leg is caught in the beartrap of society, and if you don't gnaw your leg off your spirit will starve to death.  Become the beast you already know you should be, deep down inside, and the taste in your mouth won't be your own blood, it will be the taste of freedom.  Play Goat Simulator.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												Alright, so this my first time reviewing a game on Steam, and I felt I had to do it because this game is really awesome. It's huge in every sense of the word - long, hard (that's what she said :P) and has a level of freedom you wouldn't expect from a game more than ten years old. You can do pretty much everything you want - sleep, grill meat, forge weapons, make potions, skin animals and take their teeth and even smoke pot and sell it for profit - and go anywhere you want in the game's world without a quest asking you to go there.The sun rises and sets, NPC sleep, wake up, work, gather to talk with each other, etc. etc.Being a simulator, the development of the character is always important in such a genre, and Goat simulator really shines in that department. You start as a poor weakling who gets beaten up by everyone and hardly can kick harmless little creatures called meatbugs. Then, as you complete quests and defeat enemies, you gain XP which can be converted in strength, dexterity and mana points. You go all the way to a badass warrior, a lethal ranger or a supreme mage - you chose how you want to play it.As for the bad parts, I just can think of one: the game is VERY buggy, and that can totally ruin your game experience if you don't know how to avoid it.A few important considerations about the game if you want to play and enjoy it:- Steam doesn't provide a game manual for Goat sim, and that truly sucks. If there are some games which you can start playing without reading the manual first - most modern games carry in-game tutorials - this is NOT one of them. The controls are a bit akward and if you don't read about them first I guarantee you won't be able to play the game at all. Just visit the Steam community page and you'll easily find a link to download the official manual in PDF.- You can and you SHOULD run the game on Windows 7. My desktop computer is a Pentium IV with Windows XP, and I thought It would be better choice for this game to avoid system compatibility issues. Well, that was a mistake. The game kept crashing anywhere between 5 and 30 minutes of gameplay, especially when facing multiple foes, not to mention some inventory items didn't even show the picture. I googled it and updated all my Nvidia and sound card drivers, but the problems aforementioned remained unchanged. I was very close to quit playing the game at all, but I thought what the heck, let me try it on my laptop which runs on W 7. It got A LOT better. It only crashed about 10% of the time (ah ah), especially during the first visit to the Sleeper's temple (be sure to save a lot there) and the inventory issue got fixed. I don't know about Vista or 8, but the game seems to like Windows 7. Oh, and make sure to disable Steam interface during gameplay, or the game might not start at all.- The game allows you to save whenever you want, so make sure you take advantage of it. I suggest this not for cheating purposes, but to avoid losing your game progress due to a crash or even worse, some bug where a gate doesn't open when it was supposed to or you end up killing NPCs vital to the plot who shouldn't be allowed to die at that point of the game.- Get a walkthrough. I suggest the one by JemyM, which you can easily find online. Again, I recommend it not for cheating (you can even skip the walkthrough part per se) but for the unvaluable information it contains regarding gameplay and common bugs and how to avoid them.- Go to a place like steamcommunity.com and download the map pictures. Trust me, you will need them.- If you're more into action games, maybe this game is not for you. Through most part of the game (especially the first chapters), you keep running from place to place around the colony, doing chores for other people, looking for objects, etc. Sure, later you'll feel like an invencible killing machine - it felt VERY rewarding going back to the Old Camp and slaughtering all those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who mugged me in the beginning :P - but it takes a while to get there. Play this game for the RPG experience and the story, and you will enjoy it.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												This game is a gem. The developers are completely open and honest: this game is broke beyond repair, everything glitches, things don't work, the physics are absurd and I LOVE IT. For 9.99 I have enjoyed this game 10 times more than the last game I bought for the full retail 59.99 (which was Lego Marvel on PS4). It is so refreshing to just have a game to play in, have a silly time with, and just see what you can get away with doing. The developers obviously had a blast making this game and it really shows; every little aspect has a sort of juvenile humor about it that just feels human, instead of cookie cutter, corporately censored forced dialogue and story that AAA titles have fallen into.Yes it's buggy, yes it's glitchy, yes it's pretty atrocious in the graphical fidelity department.. but dear god it is the most fun thing I've played since discovering the GECK for Fallout :DGive this game a chance, you'll love it!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												Goat Simulator's purpose is to entertain the player by any means. This meant removing ony crash bugs because the bugs made people chuckle, allowing the player to break the game, making advanced physics calculations such as turning the goat's neck into spaghetti, and the list goes on. Its sole purpose is to be worth its $10 by making the player♥♥♥♥♥♥himself/herself in laughter. From going down a waterslide in ragdoll, to going to space, to latching onto a hillbilly's car with your tongue and clotheslining innocent bystanders, to blowing up a gas station. The entertainment is endless, and the game gives you enough activities to do. Also, you can become a demon goat, get a baseball launcher, and get a jetpack(from what I've discovered so far).In case you didn't read any of this, you can be a goat and make your neck spaghetti. So 8/10.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												There are a lot of silly simulator games out there, and this is one of them. Some of the silly ones were good, even Surgeon Simulator was good, because it was silly and funny, but it was also actually slightly difficult, and was actaully a game. This game is not really that difficult, but it does have some good and bad traits to it. You can play as an animal, which is awesome! There are a lot of hard achievements to get (as well as some very easy ones), and it's a stupid simulator game.You can play as an animal in this game, which I love. It's so hard to find games in which you can play as an animal, and that is the reason I bought this game in the first place, and in the terms of playing as an animal it really fufills it's goal. Not only can you play as a goat, but you can also play as a dinosaur, a penguin, a giraffe and a whale. As whatever you play, you can make noises and act as an animal destroying things.The achievements can be quite difficult or quite easy, the early achievements are obviously very easy, but as in any game, they get harder. Checking the achievement stats, you can see that a lot of people haven't gotten quite a few easy achievements, which makes it clear the people who play this game don't play it for the achievements. The big problem with the achievements are that you cannot get all of them unless you buy the other DLC for this game, such as the 'GoatZ' one, or the 'Payday 2' one. When there was just one DLC it was fine, but now they have released a lot more stupid DLC that has made it harder and harder to get more of the achievements. Having all the achievements to collect makes it more and more fun to replay the game and try and get the achievements.This is obviously a stupid simulator game, but you don't always need to play it as one. No matter what the game, you are always the one who chooses to play the game a certain way, no one is forcing you to play this game in a stupid way, and headbutt things, and go all ragdoll everywhere. You are playing the game like that, and there's nothing wrong with playing the game like that, as it is a sandbox game. But there's also nothing wrong with trying to get all the achievements, it's just another way to play. But despite all that, it is a stupid simulator game, and that also means it has  a lot of spontanious references to mainstream things, like Minecraft, The Hitch Hikers Guide To The Galaxy, and deadmau5. These references are at first slightly funny, as it's a reference that you know and it's in a game. But at the same time it's about as funny as Saints Row 3 or 4, it's the type of funny that is splewn across the later Saints Rows games, it's not as funny as it would have been if it was a more serious game, but with the references still in there. Having a more serious game with small funny things works more than a funny game with funny things.In the end, I can't recommend this game, as this game only draws in people who just want to experience something spontanious, and not by people who want achievements (because of the low stats) and most likely not by people who like playing animals in games (as there isn't as much of a demand for those games). If you want to play a simulator game for the silliness of the game, you could play Surgeon Simulator, as it is a much more fun game, a game with references and still a lot more difficult to play than Goat Simulator. Although this game can be quite fun to play multiplayer, so unless you want to play an animal, collect achievements or play multiplayer, then you should not buy this game, as it gets old quickley.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Do you want to succeed in life but procrastination keeps getting in your way? Buy Lag Simulator! From the developer Coffee Stain Studios comes the wonderful game Lag Simulator! This piece of brilliance is sure to make all of your goals in life to come to fruition. Many people suffer from a lack of will or horrible procrastination and so cannot get themselves to do anything with their lives but to stay at home and game, hiding behind the safe veil of their screen. And that is where Lag Simulator comes in to save the day! This game will create such an immense lag on your pc or laptop that you can’t do anything at all but stare at your screen! Yes, that’s right: only staring at your screen! And that’s when you’re still at the menu! I’ve played this game for 75 minutes and all of that time was spent waiting for the game to actually start! How lag! Truly a wonderful piece of art! Needless to say, I’ve never had more fun playing a game. However, staring blankly at my unmoving screen gave me a certain feeling.. A feeling of productivity.  Odd, I know!  But during those 75 minutes of Lag Simulator I got inspired..  Scary, yes.  Inspired to do something. And since my screen wasn’t working (nor anything else since Lag Simulator lags the whole system!) I decided to do something with my life! So passionately (Yes, passion! ) I began reading once again. I now know how to better massage people with oils and special techniques and all that. All of this thanks to Lag Simulator! I, for one, recommend buying Lag Simulator if you really want to succeed in life! For anyone not yet convinced to buy this superb game, take a look at what the developer said about it on their site: “Lag Simulator is a small, broken and stupid game. It was made in a couple of weeks so don’t expect a game in the size and scope of GTA with goats. In fact, you’re better off not expecting anything at all actually. To be completely honest, it would be best if you’d spend your $10 on a hula hoop, a pile of bricks, or maybe a real-life goat.” Apparently Lag Simulator has goats too. Who knew?

Posted: April 3, 2014
												Goat Simulator is one big joke. But a hilarious one, even if it's for an hour. Play as a glitchy, buggy goat and headbutt and run into everyone and everything you see, all the while trying to create the biggest combo you can. The game itself is also very buggy and glitchy so don't expect anything to happen your way. It's random. It's hilarious. The graphics look surprisingly good and there's a good amount of activity and variety available in the map, but you'll probably get bored within a few hours. But, you should give it a try anyway.[Rating: 72/100]

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												This is neither a game, nor a simulation. You have no objective as the player, so it cannot be considered a game. I shouldn't have to explain why this isn't any kind of simulation. It's a sandbox, a very featureless, buggy sandbox. After 15 minutes of dicking around, you'll have experienced everything it has to offer, and there's no absolutely no reason to keep going after that.I'd argue this shouldn't cost more than a couple of bucks, but it definitely isn't worth $10. Heed the developers' own warning: "Goat Simulator is a completely stupid game and, to be honest, you should probably spend your money on something else, such as a hula hoop, a pile of bricks, or maybe pool your money together with your friends and buy a real goat."Don't waste your money.

Posted: April 2, 2014
												Being a goat, I can tell you that it's hard to get an accurate representation of yourself in any form of media. Finally we have a proper portrait of what it's like to be one of my own kind! It's a flawless representation and I applaud the makers for doing this. My only complaint is that we do not have a king-goat. We are a proud democracy and have not followed a dictatorship for at least 320 some odd years. Other than that, perfect!All hail our lord and savior the blood goat!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												A masterfully done metphor that contemplates our place in the universe.  Goats.  Our world pays so little homage to this creature, but this game does such a perfect job as to underline the importance of it in our modern world.  This game does an amazing job at answering important questions pertaining to life, the universe, and everything.The game itself is nothing short of a masterpiece.  Out of the plethora of games in the genre, this is, by far, the best goat simulation game I've ever played.  The realism in it is absolutely stunning, from the revolutionary next-gen graphics to the pinpointed level of realism achieved.  Goat Simulator is a must-play for any gamer, as well as anyone else, human or goat.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												FINALLY! After years of planning, hoping, and consideration of possible repercussions, a team of elite game developers have stepped up to the age old challenge of answering one of life's oldest questions; What is it like to be a goat? Wonder no more, my friends, for we stand upon the precipice of a new era. An era where man must no longer toil in the filth, averting his eyes from the heavens, but may now cast his gaze upwards towards the powers he may not yet understand and say "I defy you, universe! The time has come where my brothers and I may toss asunder our instruments of ignorant game making and firmly grab hold of the wispy understanding of our own lives that has for so long eluded our desperate grabs! I need not accept my own reality, for through the virtues of human understanding and knowledge, your secrets have been pried open for the whole world to see and learn from! I shall no longer recite oaths of humility toward your once omnipotent presence, for the blessed day has come where the shackles of oppression fall from my tired wrists, and I may reach toward the heavens and pluck from the tree of enlightenment the luscious fruit of power that we were told was poison! Our drowned world is inversed, and life is revealed to us, as mankind is no longer unable to feel what may have slipped between our fingers in the first sad centuries of our lives! We are not vulnerable to your malevolent wrath, oh malicious gods! For we, are leigon, we are undertanding, we are power, we are all, we are Goats!"

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												SINCE THE DAWN OF THE INTERNETS. Mankind has sought a way in which to simulate the life of a goat. They said it couldn't be done! But, after years of science fiction movies about goat simulator video games we have finally reached the apex of civilization: goat simluator 2014. Eons from now when mankind is long extinct and archeaologists from an alien species are excavating our ruins to piece together what kind of culture we had it is my belief that Goat Simulator 2014 will be the key artifact that redeems our species and convinces them to take DNA from mosquitoes frozen in tree sap in order to clone humans and let us live in their intergalactic zoo forever. Oh theres also a jetpack....

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												I would just like to say, before I begin, that yes, I think this is the greatest game of all time. There is no other game in the entire universe, from now until the end of time that will compare to the greatness that is this game.You may say to yourself "My my, this is a big claim you're making. Exactly what is it about this game that makes it so great?". Well, let me tell you a story.Back when I was 11 years old, I was at school (bear in mind it was a rural area too, so there was lots of fields and farm animals around). I was in class, staring out the window, distracting myself from the boring lessons I had to endure. Sometimes, I would stare out into the fields and sky, contemplating what it would feel like to be out there, totally free to run around as a goat. I often pretended I was a goat at home, when I was alone in my beadroom, running around in circles destroying all of my toys, video games and things in my closet. This felt like it was representing the urge to release myself from the house I was living in and roam around in nature with all the other animals.For about 10 years since then, I was told to suppress my urge to become a goat. My parents didn't want to continuously purchase new toys and games for me to play with (which in hindsight was fair enough too, considering they would break every time I acted like a goat), and during that time, I felt alone. No one was around to understand how I felt. The urge to run around completely naked as a goat, breaking everything, was all but a distant memory, a shadow of my former self that I regretted to have. For a time, I nearly forgot about doing it at all.That was until this game came along.I played it, and played and played it. It changed by life. All the old feelings and urges came flooding back to me as soon as I started licking cars as they drive by. The wrecking of people's houses reminding me of those times as a kid when I would do the same thing in my bedroom. It felt like the developers truly understood how I feel, after all these years searching for someone who had the same hopes and dreams as me.As a result of playing this game, I have now started organizing meetups at night for likeminded people, and we run on all fours throughout the night, around the fields near my old school amongst other goats. Luckily we can get away with making goat noises when we're surrounded by them. No one seems to notice, thankfully. I hope, at one point, we can run through our nearest city as goats at some point, even if it's in goat costumes.And that is why I think this is the greatest game of all time. If anyone at Coffee Stain Studios reads this, I am personally thanking you for becoming an inspiration for me to create the new 'Goaty' fandom.Sincerely,Bob

content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Goat Simulator is the latest in hircine emulation technology by developer Coffee Stain Studios, who you may remember as the developers of the not-so-goatish Sanctum games. The game is, as far as I can tell, the premium representation of farm life, in terms of goats, and shows the perfect flow of the life-cycle of the goat itself; doing stunts off of explosive cars is just an example of such things you can experience in this third-person open-world goat-em-up.All jokes aside, Goat Simulator is a collaborative effort by the guys at Coffee Stain which takes pride in it's stupendous outrageousness, your goat can get a jetpack and fly around the packed, albeit small, map that it calls it's home, or would you rather drop peasant goats from the sky as the queen of all that is goaty? Want to imbue the powers of the Goat Devil himself into a singularity of goat *I mean "out"* of this world proportions? You can do that. Or just interested in floppin' it up with the new-fangled "ragdoll-key"? Why not?!  When it comes to it, Goat Simulator is a buggy mess, and it embraces that- it's advertised as a "feature". However, while Goat Simulator's joke is very funny (or terrible, depending on your kind of humour) it can quickly go stale, after playing for about an hour, the lack ofthings to do has been getting to me, there are modifiers you can use, but there are very limited amounts of them. Goat Sim relies on experimentation but after a while there really isn't much to experiment with.  It's hard to review a game like Goat Simulator, while it's a glitch-filled, ugly, and very small world, it uses that to it's advantage, the devs would say "It's buggy but who cares because it's meant too be like that?" and honestly I don't know whether to applaud or condemn Coffee Stain for that. At it's best Goat Simulator is a hilarious monstrosity but at it's worst it descends into monotony. I believe that the Steam Workshop will keep this game alive, however it requires a motive for modding in the first place, and at the price it's at, I don't think it'll get much of that. Goat Simulator is £6.99 here in the UK or around $9.99 USD or €8.99 EUR. Personally, I'd wait until it came down in price if you're interested in some goat based action. I can't really reccomend this game but I can't push you away from it. If you're good with slapstick generally silly humour then this might be for you, if not then keep a watch for major price drops. I'd reccomend waiting anyway. Hazwold out.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												I knew my life would be over the second I purchased this game. My sweaty palms have been clenched to my desk, while I was sitting on the edge, waiting for this game to finally become playable. As the download bar rose in front of me, the golden sun rose at dawn, and the birds were flying backwards, I knew something wasn't right. All I could hear were goats "baaah"-ing in the distance, when suddenly, the play button finally appeared on the title.As I reached my mouse over, everything went black. All I could remember was pressing my left index finger down on the button. I then slowly opened my eyes, to find millions of goat lives flashing before them. I finally understood the way of the goat, my time had come. I realized 60 seconds had passed, but this was enough to know my objective. While it was still fuzzy, I stepped into a large field. In the distance were some humans, enjoying themselves. Cars litered the streets, and houses sat on the horizon. As I entered this town, It seemed like these humans didn't want anything to do with me. All I could do was eat grass and watch the day go past me. I then slowly stumbled into one of their BBQ parties, the humans seemed like they were having a nice time "socializing". It seemed that they didn't care much for me neither, in this moment it felt like no one cared about me, and there was no reason I was in this world, doing my goatly duties without any other goat-pals. One of the humans then flipped the patty on the grill, and it was then when he mumbled..."These goat-burgers seem a little burnt"My pupils reduced to nothing. I figured out why I was the only one, and was greatly disturbed. There was now nothing I could do but run away, so these humans couldn't find me for my deliciousness. Running into the forest, I stopped to notice that, this wasn't what I was here to do, there had to be a reason, and I was just running from it. I had to do this for the greater good.With my rage-induced horns held high, I rammed into the grill, and the humans went flying. It was then where I found out my tongue was stuck to said grill, this was now my weapon. Crashing through a house, swinging the grill into every posession they owned, I got a start on my revenge before getting stuck in a wall.My tongue slapped into a nearby car, and in an act of rebellion, the driver took off without any warning. Flipping around without any control, I let go and flew into the sky, and landed by a nearby gas station. Flying into it at high speeds, this was how it ended for my journey. In a burst of light, I was set off sky high.The world then looked so small from thousands of feet in the sky. I knew there was no stopping, and I was fine with that. Going out of the skybox and past the inter-dimensional plain, I hoped that what I had done had inspired goats from now on. Everything then went white.It's a neat game.

Goat Simulator is a must-play for any gamer, as well as anyone else, human or goat.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												Pac-Man Championship Edition seemed like the perfect Xbox Live Arcade game when it arrived back in 2007 -- but an even better version is now available on PlayStation Network. Somehow, gaming's oldest mascot is delivering one of the most exciting games of the year. More mazes, more modes, more ghosts...lots more ghosts, actually. This "deluxe" version takes everything that made Championship Edition great and adds a bunch of cool new stuff. It's like taking a great white shark and adding laser beam eyes and saw blades that shoot out of its mouth.Pac-Man Championship Edition DX is all about gunning for a high score. Games are timed, so you need to eat as many pellets, fruits, and ghosts as possible before the clock stops. You don't die as often as you did in the original Pac-Man, you earn plenty of extra lives, and you have many bombs at your disposal to get out of tight spots. (Yes, Pac-Man can now trigger bombs that send all of the ghosts back to their hideout.) Without much fear of death, you can focus on the one thing that matters: representing on the online score boards.Pac-Man now has many more ghosts to contend with. Like, a hundred more. You'll see the spirits sleeping around a maze, and as Pac-Man whizzes by they'll wake up and give chase. Hold off on eating a Power Pellet long enough and you may find dozens of ghosts trailing behind you in a long conga line. Finally grabbing that Power Pellet and devouring a hundred ghosts in a row is one of the most satisfying things I've done in a game this year. This is also a key technique in getting those high scores.While the first Championship Edition was super fun, there were only a couple of mazes and modes. DX has nine mazes, most of which are new creations that offer a lot of variety. For example, Spiral has several coils that are easy to get trapped in. Dungeon, on the other hand, has long, cramped corridors. Each maze also has many game options such as Score Attack, Time Trials, and Ghost Combos (see how many ghosts you can eat with one Power Pellet). When you first dive into Championship Edition DX, only the standard Championship II course is unlocked, but each round you play usually unlocks a new maze or mode.Like I said, it's all about the high score, and Championship Edition DX provides many friendly ways to see how you rank against the competition. You can comb through the leaderboards for extensive data on all the many maps and modes, but there are other really nice touches: your current ranking is displayed right on the title screen, the Course Select screen, and again within the menu for each maze.Pac-Man Championship Edition DX also looks and sounds great. You can select from a variety of maze skins and character designs for each game, running from the 3D Pac-Mania characters to pixilated retro sprites. The lively electronic soundtrack builds in intensity as the game timer ticks down and always gets me leaning forward in my chair.THE VERDICTPac-Man Championship Edition DX boasts simple, addictive gameplay that will have you competing for high scores on the score boards for months. Everything that made the first game a hit is still here, accompanied by a bunch of new mazes, modes, and ghosts -- all for $10. It's hard to imagine a more perfect PlayStation Network game. This is a master class in game design: you will understand it instantly, enjoy it instantly, and want to play again and again.10/10 like skyrim but with guns

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												The most beautifully immersive game I've ever played. Running around licking cars is everybody's dream. And this game lets you live it. This game is life itself personified and moreso. I had no life until I had a Goat Simulator.This game is truly limitless, if not for its authentic goat noises to the ability to run off the map without spazzing out everywhere and teleporting to a random place with a glitched neck. It has a little bit that caters for everyone.My favourite part of Goat Simulator is I can finally achieve my lifelong goal of becoming a goat. I can feel the light on my furry nostrils as my devil horns rule over my sacrifices. I can become the tall goat of the Savannah, never before discovered or named quite so fondly. Although it is not quite the same as putting my hooves on daily and experiencing first hand my goatish complexion, Goat Simulator establishes the balance between reality and goats. Indicating there truly is a goat within us all. For the human race is born goats.                                     This game has made me a better person.                                                                  Amen.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												This game is unique. Truly, truly unique. In an age where most video games do take themselves seriously (as is understandable in a world that still somehow downplays video gaming as a valid, competitive piece of the entertainment industry as a whole), it is absolutely refreshing to see a game like this come out that's not trying to be a masterpiece, or tell an in-depth story. Goat Simulator is ridiculous, colorful, somewhat pointless, hilarious, and a ton of fun.I had an argument with my best friend, who said he thought it was ridiculous this game was getting so much attention because the Meta-Critic score left much to be desired. I think he missed the whole point.Goat Simulator has glitches. The world exists for no reason other than for you to rampage through it as a goat. The people who walk through this world will literally run into things such as street posts and fall down in a pile of tangled limbs. I saw one guy walk up over a concrete guardrail and into a river, where he proceeded to float down the river without trying to swim to safety. The physics don't make sense in this game and are barely realistic. The game has a ton of technical flaws. You get stuck. You can fall through floors and fly through walls. And yes, the frame rate drops frequently, particularly when I try to jetpack my goat into space, just as I burst through the earth's atmosphere.THAT'S the point. That throughout all of its flaws, it is still a hilarious ride through a ridiculous premise of a game that is not meant to win any awards, it is meant to be FUN. It is meant to be hilarious. It is meant to be there for you when you're having a bad day and just want to launch a game for a few minutes to feel better. To be honest, half of the time glitches happen, they're hilarious. They add to the game and are not a detriment at all. Even the frame rate drops don't bother me, because...I mean, come on. My goat is going to space with a freaking jetpack. The frame rate drop feels NECESSARY with something that epic. I recommend this game to pretty much everyone. It's cheap as it is, and on sale it's a steal. At the very least, you'll have a lot of fun and laughs for a few hours in a game so ridiculous it's a miracle it exists. This is a game that exists solely for fun and entertainment value, and that is what it succeeds at.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												Goat Simulator is a lot of fun, it's filled with amazing bugs and glitches, it's got a lot of secrets to it to discover and it's the first single-player game I've had the most fun with for a while. It's a bit pricey, however, what I don't think people understand is that there are going to be a few free updates with more content and there is a workshop and a full SDK for the game. The workshop is slowly getting content and a new update is going to be in May including a new map. I've completed every challenge and gained every achievement, yet I find myself coming back to the game even after 18 hours. If you are willing to give a bit of cash to support some independent developers and to have fun and laugh at some incredible glitches I'd say buy this game.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												When I first laid eyes on this game, it was April 1st 2014 and I was highly amused by Steam's version of an April Fool's joke; because, a goat simulator, come on! However, it did puzzle me how much work they had put into the delightful screencaps, and it almost seemed real and ready to buy. (Needless to say; I was even more puzzled when the game remained in the store even after April 1st.)Then, some months later, a friend recommended it to me, and when it was on sale, I thought; okay, why not?Now I should mention that I am a busy student and have my library filled with unfinished games because I have barely time to play. And at the time when I bought Goat Simulator, I hadn't played anything for more than an hour in a while.I bought Goat Simulator, with the MMO Simulator already implemented, and whoa, in the first week I managed to play 26 hours in total; easily surpassing my general playtime over the past months. I was hooked. And I remain hooked. 10/10

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Great character development and beautiful storyline. The ending made me cry. 10/10Seriously though. This game has a lot of fun achievements. You will need all the dlc (besides the soundtrack) to get them all.I will now do the rest of this review entirely from an achievement hunter perspective.Considering there are over 100 achievements, I can't say that this is the best game for achievement hunters looking to add to their perfect game count, but even the hardest of achievements in this game are obtainable within at most an hour of play (with the hardest being the trophy collecting tasks).Each DLC comes with a good amount of achievements, most of which involve interacting with something located somewhere in the map (each DLC has a new map), and one where you need to collect all the hidden trophies (there are steam guides for everything, so it's not too hard).So like I said before; if you are hoping to get every achievement in this game, be prepared to spend a fair bit of time. Otherwise, going after these achievements are a lot of fun, and even if you aren't an achievement collector, the achievements can give you something extra to do.If achievement collectors even exist on Steam, I hope this review helped them.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												I play many types of simulation games. I'm a huge fan of ARMA, realistic flight sims and naval warfare sims.So, you can take my word that this is one of the most well researched simulations I have ever played. I now know the experience of being a goat. It's a shame that some people will discount this game as not being realistic enough. They prefer to have goat uniform inspections and to take 30 minutes acquiring their gear in order to goat up.I say nay to these goat ropers. You should spend some time with real goats. They do not say their names and goat ranks before entering an APC. They simply enter. You will know true fear when you look a goat in their weird rectangular pupils. 10/10

Posted: July 25, 2014
												Goat simulator is a fun idea, and it has alot of wacky moments and it is a joy to play.  It honestly is.But I cannot give it a positive review at the time of writing.  There are only developer maps (One I cannot even play.)  It kinda boils down to... bugs are a feature.   I don't mind bugs in games, some of them have bugs that turned out for the better, some games have bugs that break the game.  Some of Goat simulators bugs are kinda neat, but the game almost bricked my computer, causing blue screens, lockups, and a brown screen upon rebooting once.The game is fun, it is, but the fun is thin, it runs out, once you do...everything thats pretty much it, just rense repeate, I think the developers are banking on fan made content to carry the lifespan on, but no offence to people who create great content, I prefer what the devloper makes, so maybe the fan made stuff saves it.  I wouldn't know.I would wait on buying the game, if what is shown on youtube looks appealing just watch that a few more times.  I strongly urdge the developers to review their policy on bugs with the game, I do not have a top end PC, and that may be why this game almost bricked it.  I'll write a more positive review when some of the issues have been addressed, bugs have been fixed and probably when it is out of early access.I really want to like this game.
